p: TPC and TFC of herbs: The TPC and TFC of the ten materials were determined (Table 1). The TPC values ranged from 2.05 ± 0.16 to 91.59 ± 0.00 mg GAE/g DW, which was a difference of more than 40-fold. The three highest TPC values were found for S. officinalis (91.59 ± 0.00 mg GAE/g DW), C. chinensis (50.15 ± 1.14 mg GAE/g DW), and P. lobata root (45.06 ± 0.07 mg GAE/g DW). The lowest TPC values were found for G. uralensis and A. senticosus; both were below 10 mg GAE/g DW. The highest three TFC values were found for S. officinalis (14.93 ± 0.24 mg QE/g DW), C. chinensis (7.39 ± 0.39 mg QE/g DW), and P. lobata root (6.84 ± 0.08 mg QE/g DW); in contrast, the lowest three TFC values were found in A. senticosus, C. heracleifolia, and A. kravanh, all of which were below 1 mg QE/g DW. Our results revealed that S. officinalis showed the strongest in vitro antioxidant activities, possibly because it contained the highest contents of phenols and flavonoids.
